item.title: MongoDB: When comparing dates of type DateTime you need to convert strings to ISODate
item.description:
Pontifications

  • i.e. the following MongoDB query doesn't work:
{"Developer Reply Text": {$ne: null}, 'developer_last_updated_time': 
  {$gte:  "2018-05-16T00:00:00Z"}}
  • but the following does work
{"Developer Reply Text": {$ne: null}, 'developer_last_updated_time': {$gte: { $date: "2018-05-16T00:00:00Z"} }}
  • this also works and is the form I prefer since it seems less complicated to me:
{"Developer Reply Text": {$ne: null}, 'developer_last_updated_time': {
  '$gte': ISODate("2018-05-16T00:00:00Z") }}

item.title: The People's Internet: Good stuff as well as bad stuff of course!
item.description:
Pontifications

  • The people's internet will be overlayed on top of the existng commercial internet I wrote yesterday .
  • This doesn't mean it's full of bad stuff or questionable stuff. It can and should be just as diverse and a force for good.

item.title: The People's Internet: Slow, decentralized and not subject to takedown
item.description:
Pontifications

  • The people's internet will be overlayed on top of the existng commercial internet.
  • It will be slow, encrypted, decentralized and not subject to takedown which can happen at any layer with the commercial internet (DNS, WiFi, Wireless, servers, clouds, etc etc)

item.title: Mikeysax: How to install MongoDB 3.6 on Windows 10 Subsystem for Linux
item.description:
Pontifications

  • Mikeysax's gist: From Install Mongo with WSL for Windows.

QUOTE

sudo apt-key adv --keyserver hkp://keyserver.ubuntu.com:80 --recv 2930ADAE8CAF5059EE73BB4B58712A2291FA4AD5
echo "deb [ arch=amd64,arm64 ] https://repo.mongodb.org/apt/ubuntu xenial/mongodb-org/3.6 multiverse" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/mongodb-org-3.6.list
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install -y mongodb-org

This will install the most stable version of mongod, 3.6 at time of writing. If you want to install a different version please refer to the link above.

END QUOTE

item.title: Potential TensorFlow project: Use Human in the loop to train on 50 or less Firefox for Android Google Play Store reviews for positive and negative sentiment and keyword extraction?!?
item.description:
Pontifications

  • I think sentiment is definitely doable with TensorFlow
  • Not sure about keyword extraction, it might just be word clustering?!?
  • How many reviews would have to be randomly sampled? Maybe 50 per month in English?
  • Can do this in German and other languages, right?

item.title: De-ranting: Making non constructive feedback visible only to the person who posted it
item.description:
Pontifications

  • I'm a wee bit tired :-) of ranting, insults and other non-constructive feedback
  • I suggest that this non-constructive text be marked by admins from all of the websites that I work on and that once marked, have it visible only to the people who posted the non-constructive text. (The constructive-feedback text if any would be unaltered and visible to all)
  • Examples would be google play store reviews. Volunteers who are replying to Google Play Store reviews shouldn't have to read endless insults when replying to reviews.
  • What's the best way to do this? An add-on? A web app?

item.title: Stephen Downes: There's no one best way to learn computer programming
item.description:
Pontifications

  • How does Stephen do this? Since I learned about him in the early 2000s he's been concisely and beautifully summarizing things over at downes.ca at oldaily. Amazing body of work this alone! But wait there's more! He gives talks and he writes essays on his half an hour blogspot blog.
  • "This is a really good but conceptually difficult essay with an important point to make: there's no one best way to teach computer programming. There's no natural ordering of concepts from foundational to advanced." <--- read Stephen's summary post, Programming Paradigms and Beyond AND the whole PDF .

item.title: How difficult is it to write an Android app that works with Android 4.1, 5, 6,7, 8 and the Android 9 which will be released by September?
item.description:
Pontifications

  • Serious and honestly not really a work related question:
    • How difficult is it to write an Android app that works with Android 4.1, 5, 6,7, 8 and the Android 9 which will be released by September?
    • Is it better to write multiple apps, e.g. one for 4.1 and one for 5,6 and one for 7, 8 and 9?
  • How much Android functionality do you lose as you move from Android 9 down to 4.1?
  • I've been supporting Android apps since 2012 so I know the answers to most of the above questions, but maybe there's somebody out there who can give me a 2018 answer.

item.title: Twitter smytes customers and its 3 out of 5 spam comments encapsulates today's internet, central control and entropy and power distibution
item.description:
Pontifications

  • Twitter smytes customers (tl;dr Twitter shuts down API overnight without notice that Indiegogo and lots of other folks rely on for social media spam filtering and other stuff) and its 3 out of 5 spam comments encapsulates today's internet: central control and entropy and power distibution
  • "Tyranny" of centralized services including APIs sad face

item.title: iodide is just another example of everything in your browser, what's next R? Ruby? Yes Please!
item.description:
Pontifications

  • Can't wait until we can do Ruby and R in the browser as well!
